comments.commentBody:
Garrett Clay --- The people who told everybody that Fukushima couldn't happen were the world's seismologists and oceanographers. There was only one seismologist who thought that the Tohoku fault could produce a moment magnitude 9.0 fault. Even so, no oceanographer would have predicted such a large tsunami from one the the world's most severe earthquakes.

TMI was solely operator error and the NRC now requires much better training. In addition, the new Gen3 units under construction have many more safety features. For example the Westinghouse AP-1000s currently under construction in southeastern US are walk away safe for 72 hours; that means no operator actions are necessary for 72 hours which means there is plenty of time to take considered action.

The so-called waste problem is technically solved; it is only a matter of political will. See my replies to other comments.

Globalization, robots and computers haven't caused average worker's income to fall, as Annie Lowrie writes.

The fact that the bottom 70% of workers with college degrees has seen no raise for 10 years contradicts the assertion that those with more education are not suffering.

Why should any voter believe that economists in general agree, that sequestration has caused less damage than expected, and only taken some money out of workers' and businesses' pockets? It's true for those ignoring the silently starving whose meals-on-wheels and cancer treatments or unemployment stopped, and those ignoring the economists who have documented how austerity kills.

Why does this summary of the problems that President Obama listed report on things he did not mention, and ignore the role of the tax and regulatory systems, that the powerful have purchased?

Why report a jobless recovery as a normal cyclical recovery taken hold? Why insinuate that the president focused on structural problems (mainstream media code for slashing safety nets)?

Unlike taxes, the president did no selling of safety net cuts, which are what supply siders and austerians want, and have been proven to worsen recessions and even cause their return.

The administration and Democrats HAVE proposed jobs acts and budgets, if the reporter wants to know what specific policies have been proposed.

Anyone can take a look at the House Democrat's Budget For All, to see solutions to all the problems the president described.

"Gay has nothing to do with it"??  It seems to me that it has EVERYTHING to do with it!  If his friend weren't gay, he'd have no reason to ask his question in the first place.  It is her homophobia that makes this an issue.

Terrado should tell this woman that while he'd love to have her show him around her city, it would be impolite to leave a travel companion alone for the entire day, and perhaps the two of them could catch up over breakfast instead.

The decision to be polite is then hers. Either she extends her tour offer to both, or she gets 2 hours over breakfast. If she extends the tour offer, ask her if she has a delightful female friend that could also accompany the group, so that nobody feels like a third wheel.

Gay has nothing to do with it. It's an etiquette question, through and through.

Mark Renfrow - Dallas --- I don't care whether they call it Gen3+ or Gen4.  The fact is that it is fast reactor design which proved itself by 30 years of problem-free operation.  GE-Hitachi has offered the British a brace of S_Prism fast reactors so the British can consume their excess bomb plutonium whilst generating 6222 MW.  GE-Hitachi is confident enough to state that if it does not work the British do not have to pay for it.
It is not the control, it is the lack of cooperation. Regan definitely had a congress that worked with him on many bills. Witness SSI reform .
Mark Renfrow - Dallas --- I gather you've never been in the Navy nor had a conversation with a retired Navy nuke-head...
For clarity--there isn't enough "Paleo Diet" food to feed everyone.
And, any suggestions that you have for doubling (or in my case quadrupling) the recipe would also be greatly appreciated.

Like many diabetics, I test my blood glucose levels frequently. Like others who do so, I know from experience that there is a sizable difference in the way my body responds to whole grains compared with highly processed grains such as white flour and white rice.

I am not sure if this is true. In India, where a bulk of rice is consumed in the South (and firmly west of Bengal) and in Bengal, rice is cooked several ways without frying (ground and steamed into cakes, steamed directly, steamed and beaten flat, broken and steamed, parboiled, etc---and I am not even considering consumption in the form of flour). For a few specific dishes, yes, rice is fried first. But the miniscule dishes that actually involve frying pale in comparison with the diversity of cooking techniques. This is quite true in the far east as well. In both these places, rice is an important, well explored ingredient---not a relative curiosity like in Europe.

From the link you posted, I think you are conflating your local Indian restaurant (which---even in NY---are almost exclusively from one small part of NW India or NE Pakistan) with Indian cuisine. It is true that most Indian restaurants across Europe and US feature cuisine from NW India and NE Pakistan, but this is more a reflection of migration patterns (and a visibility---to the west---issue) rather than of Indian cuisine.
And to prevent a bitter taste, quinoa also needs to be rinsed prior to cooking.

Raw garlic in pesto is heavenly, just make sure everyone at the table has some so everyone has dragon breath together! If you let it oxidate for about 5 mins after smashing the garlic, some of the bite abates, especially if you remove any green sprout from the clove centre.

Anchovies are also pure umami delight, and some of the best memories of my childhood are munching on raw sweet corn in the field with my Gramma, back when you had to pick, shuck and steam it asap before it went starchy ( the old, non-sugar enhanced kind only stayed sweet about 20 mins)

So, to each her own! You are missing some great food with your attitude...
You could try "Taste 5 Umami Paste" which has anchovies in a tomato/mushroom base -- it's fabulous and isn't the least bit fishy.  He'd never know >;D
okay, thank you I guess.....
That's a botanical distinction, not a culinary one.
Quinoa is technically not a grain.  Grains are the seeds of monocots, Quinoa is a dicot.
agree I do!

Arrowhead Mills makes an excellent puffed brown rice with nothing else on it. I believe there might be other brands also. But they won't be found at places like Fairway for a while yet, if ever. If you're serious about healthy food, even though things are getting better at the supermarkets you should get to know a good health food store or two.
I am very interested in what solutions Mr. Castro can find for this "lack personal and social standards".  We could use a few pointers.
gosh, I have no problem with people cutting up pigs in the street, I don't think it's a put down of Cuba to show that.  I wish we had more earthy stuff like that going on here.
Also, consider how many immensely talented athletes and artists have come from Cuba despite the politics.  The realization alone is staggering.

I don't think so. The article is fair in establishing Cuba as historically a gleaming example of a well-functioning society that has fallen into disarray as a result of generations of economic desperation and political oppression.
The republican theme is out there' Obama can't lead and that is why the economy is bad'. America, wake up. Read Krugman if you want to understand economics not Limbaugh or Bohner.

Carole of San Diego is right.
I was in Havana in '55, when Trujillo dictated with the help of the Florida
Mafia. 12 yr old prostitutes in the streets. Filth everywhere in the stench
of urine, except in the big hotel and Copacabana area. Sewerage in the harbor. I was sympathetic to Castro until I learned of his own ruthlessness with his people. But health care and education were promoted, then not paid a decent wage. There must be a 1% in Cuba, has to be. Maybe military? Anyway folks, I live in Hawaii, put up with boom boxes in the middle of the night, homeless people in the parks and harbors, anywhere there is running water and a toilet. And then there is Waikiki. Any prostitutes? Duh. As the kids say. Wages have not improved more than 2% in 23 years.

The US still pays educated professionals fairly well, as in medicine
and dentistry and veterinarian practice. Lawyers everywhere. But you
could find the same social defeat and problems in Bangor, Maine, or in a smaller, rural village. What is the common denominator? Wages, that give people a sense of value and purpose, a future even kids may want.
Even if it is in public service, that Right wing battered "socialism." Cuba
is a decent study for ourselves.Kids will steal for sneakers. Politicians and CEO's will hide their money in the Caymans, as if they have little faith in the future of the nation.
One has to love the myopic college professor's assessment: “Individual responsibility toward the collective is very low.”  Where except in early Bolshevik Russia was it ever high??

Jason Shapiro --- Consider your automobile insurance. If you cause a life-altering injury, what then?

Mark Renfrow - Dallas --- There are at least two companies specializing in liability insurance for the world's nuclear power plants. It is quite a good business, in part because there are almost no payouts.
